name: Purchased goods and services
Emissions calculation methodology: Direct data was collected to determine emissions tied to tier 1 purchased goods and services. Data was collected through CDP Supply Chain and calculated using emissions reported directly to Kellogg, normalized by revenue. When data was inaccurate or not provided, emissions were extrapolated based on sector averages.

name: Capital goods
Emissions calculation methodology: Total expenditure in USD for capital goods projects in 2016 was used to estimate emissions on the basis of the 2002 Carnegie Mellon Economic Input Output LCA model. The emission factor for the category of “Other industrial machinery manufacturing was used,” and an inflation correction factor of 1.3341 was used to adjust for inflation.

name: Fuel-and-energy-related activities
Emissions calculation methodology: Emissions calculated using primary data from reported energy use type and EPA emission factors. Emission factors were drawn from the EPA instead of Defra because 50% of Kellogg’s business is in the US. Emissions from T&D losses were calculated based on the US average grid loss of 4.95%.

name: Upstream transportation and distribution
Emissions calculation methodology: To calculate upstream transportation and distribution, we began with 2014 raw data for seven key ingredients and associated top sourcing locations. This primary data was extrapolated to represent upstream transportation based on 2014 spend and updated based on 2018 production.

name: Waste generated in operations
Emissions calculation methodology: Using the EPA WARM model, an estimate of GHG emissions was completed using waste to landfill data from operations, including warehouses, manufacturing and office locations. A conservative estimate of 20% has been added to address waste from global warehouses and offices not tracked in KCAPP.

name: Business travel
Emissions calculation methodology: Information on flights, rental car mileage, and hotel stays are collected by our global business travel partners. A conservative estimate of 20% has been added to addresstravel arrangements made outside of this system.

name: Employee commuting
Emissions calculation methodology: Estimates were made based on the number of employees and conservative assumptions of commuting distance and mode of transportation.

name: Upstream leased assets
explanation: Emissions from Kellogg leased assets, such as offices, warehouses, and natural gas fuel cells are included in Scope 1 and 2 emissions.

name: Downstream transportation and distribution
Emissions calculation methodology: To calculate downstream transportation and distribution, we began with 2014 raw data for global production facilities, warehouses, and top regional retail locations. This primarydata was extrapolated to represent upstream transportation based on 2014 spend and updated based on 2018 production.

name: Processing of sold products
explanation: The vast majority of Kellogg products are not processed further once sold. Minor exceptions include partnerships with Burger King, in which Fruit Loops are processed into milkshakes, and Danone, where cereal is packaged with yogurt. In each of these cases, further processing is minimal and generally focused on repackaging, rather than energy intensive processing. Minimal emissions are expected to be generated in the processing of sold Kellogg products.

name: Use of sold products
explanation: The vast majority of Kellogg products do not require cooking, freezing, or refrigeration; therefore minimal emissions are expected to be generated in the use of Kellogg products.

name: End of life treatment of sold products
explanation: Packaging sizes and recyclability, product shelf life, and communicated portion control information, minimize food and packaging waste from Kellogg products. Minimal emissions are expected to be generated by the end of life treatment of Kellogg products.

name: Downstream leased assets
explanation: Kellogg has extremely minimal downstream leased assets. Emissions from these assets are estimated to be less than 1% of total Scope 3 emissions. For example, our cereal manufacturing plant in Bremen, Germany, rents out warehouse and office space and estimates that 10% of site energy is associated with this leased space. This represents approximately 2,000 MT of CO2e emissions, which is 0.02% of total Scope 3 emissions. Additional sites have similar arrangements, but emissions from downstream assets remain not relevant.

name: Investments
Emissions calculation methodology: The data used as inputs for the calculations was drawn from the investments made by Kellogg as equity investments, joint ventures, pensions and retiree healthcare. The methodology was based on an average-spend method. Each investment was assigned to a sector category found in the 2002 Carnegie Mellon Economic Input Output LCA model, which produced an emission factor for each investment category. An inflation correction factor of 1.3607 was used to adjust for inflation between 2002 and 2018. Kellogg’s share of equity in investee and the 2018 investee revenue was then multiplied by the inflation correction factor and the emission factor.

name: Other (upstream)
explanation: All relevant upstream emissions have been calculated elsewhere.

name: Other (downstream)
explanation: All relevant downstream emissions have been calculated elsewhere.

name: Consumption of purchased or acquired electricity
Consumption of purchased or acquired heat
Consumption of purchased or acquired steam
Consumption of purchased or acquired cooling
Consumption of self-generated non- fuel renewable energy
